explanation: The issue in the original code arises from the assumption that the user will always provide at least 'k' inputs. If 'k' is greater than 'n', it will lead to an IndexError when trying to access s[i] for i in range(k). The corrected line checks if 'k' exceeds 'n' and sets 'k' to 'n' to prevent any out-of-range errors when printing the sorted list.
fixed_code:
n, k = map(int, input().split())
s = [input() for _ in range(n)]
s.sort()
k = min(k, n)
for i in range(k):
  print(s[i])
